text: MISTER QUILTER IS THE APOSTLE OF THE MIDDLE CLASSES AND WE ARE GLAD TO WELCOME HIS GOSPEL
translated_text: Mr. Quilter is the apostle of the middle classes, and we are glad to welcome his gospel.

text: NOR IS MISTER QUILTER'S MANNER LESS INTERESTING THAN HIS MATTER
translated_text: Nor is Mr. Quilter's manner less interesting than his matter.

text: HE TELLS US THAT AT THIS FESTIVE SEASON OF THE YEAR WITH CHRISTMAS AND ROAST BEEF LOOMING BEFORE US SIMILES DRAWN FROM EATING AND ITS RESULTS OCCUR MOST READILY TO THE MIND
translated_text: He tells us that at this festive season of the year, with Christmas and roast beef looming before us, similarly drawn from eating and its results occur most readily to the mind.

text: HE HAS GRAVE DOUBTS WHETHER SIR FREDERICK LEIGHTON'S WORK IS REALLY GREEK AFTER ALL AND CAN DISCOVER IN IT BUT LITTLE OF ROCKY ITHACA
translated_text: He has graved doubts whether Sir Frederick Layton's work is really Greek after all, and can discover in it but little of Rocky Ithaca.

text: LINNELL'S PICTURES ARE A SORT OF UP GUARDS AND AT EM PAINTINGS AND MASON'S EXQUISITE IDYLLS ARE AS NATIONAL AS A JINGO POEM MISTER BIRKET FOSTER'S LANDSCAPES SMILE AT ONE MUCH IN THE SAME WAY THAT MISTER CARKER USED TO FLASH HIS TEETH AND MISTER JOHN COLLIER GIVES HIS SITTER A CHEERFUL SLAP ON THE BACK BEFORE HE SAYS LIKE A SHAMPOOER IN A TURKISH BATH NEXT MAN
translated_text: Lynelle's pictures are a sort of upgards and atom paintings, and Mason's exquisite ittles are as national as a jingo poem. Mr. Birkett Foster's landscapes smile at one much in the same way that Mr. Carker used to flash his teeth. And Mr. John Collier gives his sitter a cheerful slap on the back, before he says, like a shampooer and a Turkish bath. Next man!

text: IT IS OBVIOUSLY UNNECESSARY FOR US TO POINT OUT HOW LUMINOUS THESE CRITICISMS ARE HOW DELICATE IN EXPRESSION
translated_text: It is obviously unnecessary for us to point out how luminous these criticisms are, how delicate and expression.

text: ON THE GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF ART MISTER QUILTER WRITES WITH EQUAL LUCIDITY
translated_text: On the general principles of art, Mr. Krilter writes with equal lucidity.

text: PAINTING HE TELLS US IS OF A DIFFERENT QUALITY TO MATHEMATICS AND FINISH IN ART IS ADDING MORE FACT
translated_text: Painting, he tells us, is of a different quality to mathematics, and finish in art is adding more factor.

text: AS FOR ETCHINGS THEY ARE OF TWO KINDS BRITISH AND FOREIGN
translated_text: As for etchings, there are two kinds, British and foreign.

text: HE LAMENTS MOST BITTERLY THE DIVORCE THAT HAS BEEN MADE BETWEEN DECORATIVE ART AND WHAT WE USUALLY CALL PICTURES MAKES THE CUSTOMARY APPEAL TO THE LAST JUDGMENT AND REMINDS US THAT IN THE GREAT DAYS OF ART MICHAEL ANGELO WAS THE FURNISHING UPHOLSTERER
translated_text: He laments most bitterly the divorce that has been made between decorative art and what we usually call pictures. Mixed a customary appeal to the last judgment and reminds us that in the great days of art Michelangelo was the furnishing upholsterer.

text: NEAR THE FIRE AND THE ORNAMENTS FRED BROUGHT HOME FROM INDIA ON THE MANTEL BOARD
translated_text: near the fire, and the ornaments Fred brought home from India on the mental board.

text: IN FACT HE IS QUITE SEVERE ON MISTER RUSKIN FOR NOT RECOGNISING THAT A PICTURE SHOULD DENOTE THE FRAILTY OF MAN AND REMARKS WITH PLEASING COURTESY AND FELICITOUS GRACE THAT MANY PHASES OF FEELING
translated_text: In fact, he is quite severe on Mr. Ruskin for not recognizing that a picture should denote the frailty of man, and remarks with pleasing courtesy and felicitous grace that many phases of feeling

text: ONLY UNFORTUNATELY HIS OWN WORK NEVER DOES GET GOOD

translated_text: Mr. Quilter has missed his chance, for he has failed even to make himself the Tupper of Painting.

translated_text: I have remained a prisoner only because I wish to be one. And with this, he stepped forward and burst the stout chains as easily as if they had been threads.

translated_text: A minute is not a very large measure of time, and his body needed every fraction of it.

translated_text: O Lee's heart and lungs worked on at a strong, measured rate.

translated_text: When the buzzer sounded, he pulled his foil from his second startled grasp and ran forward.

text: THEN THE POWERFUL TWIST THAT THRUST IT ASIDE IN AND UNDER THE GUARD

translated_text: Hughes written a delightful part for her, and she's quite inexpressible.

translated_text: I happen to have McConnell's box for tonight, or there'd be no chance of our getting places.

translated_text: Alexander exclaimed mildly.

text: MYSELF I ALWAYS KNEW SHE HAD IT IN HER
translated_text: myself. I always knew she had it in her.

translated_text: Do you know Alexander? Maynall looked with perplexity up into the top of the handsome, and rubbed his pink cheek with his gloved finger. Do you know, I sometimes think of taking to criticism seriously myself?

text: OF COURSE HILDA IS IRISH THE BURGOYNES HAVE BEEN STAGE PEOPLE FOR GENERATIONS AND SHE HAS THE IRISH VOICE
translated_text: Of course, Hilda is Irish. Their bergoins have been stage people for generations, and she has the Irish voice.

text: IT'S DELIGHTFUL TO HEAR IT IN A LONDON THEATRE

text: AFTER HER DANCE SHE WITHDREW FROM THE DIALOGUE AND RETREATED TO THE DITCH WALL BACK OF PHILLY'S BURROW WHERE SHE SAT SINGING THE RISING OF THE MOON AND MAKING A WREATH OF PRIMROSES FOR HER DONKEY
translated_text: After her dance, she withdrew from the dialogue and retreated to the ditch wall back of Philly's burrow, where she sat singing the rising of the moon and making a wreath of prim roses for her donkey.

text: MAC CONNELL LET ME INTRODUCE MISTER BARTLEY ALEXANDER
translated_text: McConnell, let me introduce Mr. Bartley Alexander.

translated_text: The playwright gave Main Hall a curious look out of his deep-set faded eyes and made a riot face.

text: HE NODDED CURTLY AND MADE FOR THE DOOR DODGING ACQUAINTANCES AS HE WENT
translated_text: He nodded curtly and made for the door, dodging acquaintances as he went.

text: I DARE SAY IT'S QUITE TRUE THAT THERE'S NEVER BEEN ANY ONE ELSE
translated_text: I dare say it's quite true that there's never been anyone else.

text: HE'S ANOTHER WHO'S AWFULLY KEEN ABOUT HER LET ME INTRODUCE YOU
translated_text: He's another who's awfully keen about her. Let me introduce you.

text: SIR HARRY TOWNE BOWED AND SAID THAT HE HAD MET MISTER ALEXANDER AND HIS WIFE IN TOKYO
translated_text: Sir Harry Town Boud and said that he had met Mr. Alexander and his wife in Tokyo.

text: I SAY SIR HARRY THE LITTLE GIRL'S GOING FAMOUSLY TO NIGHT ISN'T SHE
translated_text: I say, Sir Harry, the little girl's going famously tonight, isn't she?

text: THE FACT IS SHE'S FEELING RATHER SEEDY POOR CHILD
translated_text: The fact is, she's feeling rather CD poor child.

text: A LITTLE ATTACK OF NERVES POSSIBLY
translated_text: a little attack of nerves possibly.

text: HE BOWED AS THE WARNING BELL RANG AND MAINHALL WHISPERED YOU KNOW LORD WESTMERE OF COURSE THE STOOPED MAN WITH THE LONG GRAY MUSTACHE TALKING TO LADY DOWLE
translated_text: He bowed as the warding bell rang, and main hall whispered, You know, Lord Westmare, of course, the stooped man with the long gray mustache, talking to Lady Dowell.

text: IN A MOMENT PEGGY WAS ON THE STAGE AGAIN AND ALEXANDER APPLAUDED VIGOROUSLY WITH THE REST

text: IN THE HALF LIGHT HE LOOKED ABOUT AT THE STALLS AND BOXES AND SMILED A LITTLE CONSCIOUSLY RECALLING WITH AMUSEMENT SIR HARRY'S JUDICIAL FROWN
translated_text: In the half-light, he looked about at the stalls and boxes and smiled a little consciously, recalling with the amusement Sir Harry's judicial frown.

text: HE LEANED FORWARD AND BEAMED FELICITATIONS AS WARMLY AS MAINHALL HIMSELF WHEN AT THE END OF THE PLAY SHE CAME AGAIN AND AGAIN BEFORE THE CURTAIN PANTING A LITTLE AND FLUSHED HER EYES DANCING AND HER EAGER NERVOUS LITTLE MOUTH TREMULOUS WITH EXCITEMENT
translated_text: He leaned forward and beamed felicitations as warmly as main hall himself when, at the end of the play, she came again and again before the curtain, panting a little and flushed. Her eyes dancing and her eager, nervous little mouth tremulous with excitement.

text: ALL THE SAME HE LIFTED HIS GLASS HERE'S TO YOU LITTLE HILDA
translated_text: All the same. He lifted his glass. Here's to you, little hilda.

text: I'M GLAD SHE'S HELD HER OWN SINCE
translated_text: I'm glad she's held her own sense.

text: IT WAS YOUTH AND POVERTY AND PROXIMITY AND EVERYTHING WAS YOUNG AND KINDLY
translated_text: It was youth and poverty and proximity, and everything was young and kindly.

text: THE LAST TWO DAYS OF THE VOYAGE BARTLEY FOUND ALMOST INTOLERABLE
translated_text: The last two days of the voyage, Bartley found almost intolerable.

text: EMERGING AT EUSTON AT HALF PAST THREE O'CLOCK IN THE AFTERNOON ALEXANDER HAD HIS LUGGAGE SENT TO THE SAVOY AND DROVE AT ONCE TO BEDFORD SQUARE
translated_text: Emerging at Houston at half past three o'clock in the afternoon, Alexander had his luggage sent to the Savoy and drove it once to Bedford Square.

text: SHE BLUSHED AND SMILED AND FUMBLED HIS CARD IN HER CONFUSION BEFORE SHE RAN UPSTAIRS
translated_text: She blushed and smiled and fumbled his card in her confusion before she ran upstairs.

text: THE ROOM WAS EMPTY WHEN HE ENTERED
translated_text: The room was empty when he entered.

text: A COAL FIRE WAS CRACKLING IN THE GRATE AND THE LAMPS WERE LIT FOR IT WAS ALREADY BEGINNING TO GROW DARK OUTSIDE
translated_text: A coal fire was crackling in the grate, and the lamps were lit, for it was already beginning to grow dark outside.

text: SHE CALLED HIS NAME ON THE THRESHOLD BUT IN HER SWIFT FLIGHT ACROSS THE ROOM SHE FELT A CHANGE IN HIM AND CAUGHT HERSELF UP SO DEFTLY THAT HE COULD NOT TELL JUST WHEN SHE DID IT
translated_text: She calls his name on the threshold, but in her swift flight across the room she felt a change in him and caught herself up so deftly that he could not tell just when she did it.

text: SHE MERELY BRUSHED HIS CHEEK WITH HER LIPS AND PUT A HAND LIGHTLY AND JOYOUSLY ON EITHER SHOULDER
translated_text: She merely brushed his cheek with her lips and put a hand lightly and joyously on either shoulder.

text: I NEVER DREAMED IT WOULD BE YOU BARTLEY
translated_text: I never dreamed it would be you, Bartley.

text: WHEN DID YOU COME BARTLEY AND HOW DID IT HAPPEN YOU HAVEN'T SPOKEN A WORD
translated_text: When did you come, Bartley, and how did it happen? You haven't spoken a word.

text: SHE LOOKED AT HIS HEAVY SHOULDERS AND BIG DETERMINED HEAD THRUST FORWARD LIKE A CATAPULT IN LEASH
translated_text: She looked at his heavy shoulders and big, determined head, fresh-forward like a catapult in leash.

text: I'LL DO ANYTHING YOU WISH ME TO BARTLEY SHE SAID TREMULOUSLY
translated_text: I'll do anything you wish me to, Bartley. She said, chum-y-l-isly.

text: HE PULLED UP A WINDOW AS IF THE AIR WERE HEAVY
translated_text: He pulled up a window as if the air were heavy.

text: HILDA WATCHED HIM FROM HER CORNER TREMBLING AND SCARCELY BREATHING DARK SHADOWS GROWING ABOUT HER EYES
translated_text: Hilda watched him from her corner, trembling and scarcely breathing, dark shadows going about her eyes.

text: IT IT HASN'T ALWAYS MADE YOU MISERABLE HAS IT
translated_text: It hasn't always made you miserable, has it?

text: ALWAYS BUT IT'S WORSE NOW
translated_text: Always, but it's worse now.

text: IT'S UNBEARABLE IT TORTURES ME EVERY MINUTE
translated_text: It's unbearable. It tortures me every minute.

text: I AM NOT A MAN WHO CAN LIVE TWO LIVES HE WENT ON FEVERISHLY EACH LIFE SPOILS THE OTHER
translated_text: I am not a man who can live two lives. He went on feverishly. Each life spoils the other.

text: I GET NOTHING BUT MISERY OUT OF EITHER
translated_text: I get nothing but misery out of either.

text: THERE IS THIS DECEPTION BETWEEN ME AND EVERYTHING
translated_text: There is this deception between me and everything.

text: AT THAT WORD DECEPTION SPOKEN WITH SUCH SELF CONTEMPT THE COLOR FLASHED BACK INTO HILDA'S FACE AS SUDDENLY AS IF SHE HAD BEEN STRUCK BY A WHIPLASH
translated_text: At that word, deception, spoken with such self-contempt, the color flashed back into Hilda's face, as suddenly as if she had been struck by a whiplash.

text: SHE BIT HER LIP AND LOOKED DOWN AT HER HANDS WHICH WERE CLASPED TIGHTLY IN FRONT OF HER
translated_text: She bit her lip and looked down at her hands, which were clasped tightly in front of her.

text: COULD YOU COULD YOU SIT DOWN AND TALK ABOUT IT QUIETLY BARTLEY AS IF I WERE A FRIEND AND NOT SOME ONE WHO HAD TO BE DEFIED
translated_text: Could you sit down and talk about it quietly, Bartley, as if I were a friend and not someone who had to be defied?

text: HE DROPPED BACK HEAVILY INTO HIS CHAIR BY THE FIRE
translated_text: He dropped back heavily into his chair by the fire.

text: I HAVE THOUGHT ABOUT IT UNTIL I AM WORN OUT
translated_text: I have thought about it until I am worn out.

text: AFTER THE VERY FIRST
translated_text: after the very first.

text: HILDA'S FACE QUIVERED BUT SHE WHISPERED YES I THINK IT MUST HAVE BEEN
translated_text: Held his face quivered, but she whispered. Yes, I think it must have been.

text: SHE PRESSED HIS HAND GENTLY IN GRATITUDE WEREN'T YOU HAPPY THEN AT ALL
translated_text: She pressed his hand gently in gratitude. Weren't you happy then, at all?

text: SOMETHING OF THEIR TROUBLING SWEETNESS CAME BACK TO ALEXANDER TOO
translated_text: Something of their troubling sweetness came back to Alexander too.

text: PRESENTLY IT STOLE BACK TO HIS COAT SLEEVE
translated_text: Presently, it's door back to his coat sleeve.

text: YES HILDA I KNOW THAT HE SAID SIMPLY
translated_text: Yes, Hilda, I know that. He said simply.

text: I UNDERSTAND BARTLEY I WAS WRONG
translated_text: I understand, Barley. I was wrong.

text: SHE LISTENED INTENTLY BUT SHE HEARD NOTHING BUT THE CREAKING OF HIS CHAIR
translated_text: She listened intently, but she heard nothing but the creaking of his chair.

text: YOU WANT ME TO SAY IT SHE WHISPERED
translated_text: You want me to say it? She whispered.

text: BARTLEY LEANED HIS HEAD IN HIS HANDS AND SPOKE THROUGH HIS TEETH
translated_text: Bartley leaned his head in his hands and spoke through his teeth.

text: IT'S GOT TO BE A CLEAN BREAK HILDA
translated_text: It's got to be a clean brake holder.

text: OH BARTLEY WHAT AM I TO DO
translated_text: Oh, Bartley, what am I to do?

text: YOU ASK ME TO STAY AWAY FROM YOU BECAUSE YOU WANT ME
translated_text: You ask me to stay away from you because you want me?

text: I WILL ASK THE LEAST IMAGINABLE BUT I MUST HAVE SOMETHING
translated_text: I will ask the least imaginable, but I must have something.

text: HILDA SAT ON THE ARM OF IT AND PUT HER HANDS LIGHTLY ON HIS SHOULDERS
translated_text: Hilda sat on the arm of it and put her hands lightly on his shoulders.

text: YOU SEE LOVING SOME ONE AS I LOVE YOU MAKES THE WHOLE WORLD DIFFERENT
translated_text: You see, loving someone as I love you makes the whole world different.

text: AND THEN YOU CAME BACK NOT CARING VERY MUCH BUT IT MADE NO DIFFERENCE
translated_text: And then you came back, not caring very much, but it made no difference.

text: SHE SLID TO THE FLOOR BESIDE HIM AS IF SHE WERE TOO TIRED TO SIT UP ANY LONGER
translated_text: She slid to the floor beside him, as if she were too tired to sit up any longer.

text: DON'T CRY DON'T CRY HE WHISPERED
translated_text: Don't cry. Don't cry," he whispered.

text: ON THE LAST SATURDAY IN APRIL THE NEW YORK TIMES PUBLISHED AN ACCOUNT OF THE STRIKE COMPLICATIONS WHICH WERE DELAYING ALEXANDER'S NEW JERSEY BRIDGE AND STATED THAT THE ENGINEER HIMSELF WAS IN TOWN AND AT HIS OFFICE ON WEST TENTH STREET
translated_text: On the last Saturday in April, the New York Times published an account of the strike complications, which were delaying Alexander's New Jersey bridge, and stated that the engineer himself was in town and at his office on West 10th Street.

text: OVER THE FIREPLACE THERE WAS A LARGE OLD FASHIONED GILT MIRROR
translated_text: Over the fireplace there was a large old-fashioned guilt mirror.

text: HE ROSE AND CROSSED THE ROOM QUICKLY
translated_text: He rose and crossed the room quickly.

text: OF COURSE I KNOW BARTLEY SHE SAID AT LAST THAT AFTER THIS YOU WON'T OWE ME THE LEAST CONSIDERATION BUT WE SAIL ON TUESDAY
translated_text: Of course, I know, Bartley," she said at last, that after this you won't owe me the least consideration. But we sail on Tuesday.

text: I SAW THAT INTERVIEW IN THE PAPER YESTERDAY TELLING WHERE YOU WERE AND I THOUGHT I HAD TO SEE YOU THAT'S ALL GOOD NIGHT I'M GOING NOW
translated_text: I saw that interview in the paper yesterday telling where you were, and I thought I had to see you. That's all. Good night. I'm going now.

text: LET ME TAKE OFF YOUR COAT AND YOUR BOOTS THEY'RE OOZING WATER
translated_text: Let me take off your coat and your boots. They're oozing water.

text: IF YOU'D SENT ME A NOTE OR TELEPHONED ME OR ANYTHING
translated_text: If you'd sent me a note or telephone to me or anything.

text: I TOLD MYSELF THAT IF I WERE REALLY THINKING OF YOU AND NOT OF MYSELF A LETTER WOULD BE BETTER THAN NOTHING
translated_text: I told myself that if I were really thinking of you and not of myself, a letter would be better than nothing.

text: HE PAUSED THEY NEVER DID TO ME
translated_text: He paused. They never did to me.

text: OH BARTLEY DID YOU WRITE TO ME
translated_text: Oh, Bartley. Did you write to me?

text: ALEXANDER SLIPPED HIS ARM ABOUT HER
translated_text: Alexander slipped his arm about her.

text: I THINK I HAVE FELT THAT YOU WERE COMING
translated_text: I think I have felt that you were coming.

text: HE BENT HIS FACE OVER HER HAIR
translated_text: He bent his face over her hair.

text: AND I SHE WHISPERED I FELT THAT YOU WERE FEELING THAT
translated_text: And I, she whispered, I felt that you were feeling that.

text: BUT WHEN I CAME I THOUGHT I HAD BEEN MISTAKEN
translated_text: But when I came, I thought I had been mistaken.

text: I'VE BEEN UP IN CANADA WITH MY BRIDGE AND I ARRANGED NOT TO COME TO NEW YORK UNTIL AFTER YOU HAD GONE
translated_text: I've been up in Canada with my bridge and I arranged not to come to New York until after you had gone.

text: THEN WHEN YOUR MANAGER ADDED TWO MORE WEEKS I WAS ALREADY COMMITTED
translated_text: Then when your manager added two more weeks, I was already committed.

text: I'M GOING TO DO WHAT YOU ASKED ME TO DO WHEN YOU WERE IN LONDON
translated_text: I'm going to do what you asked me to do when you were in London.

text: ONLY I'LL DO IT MORE COMPLETELY
translated_text: Only I'll do it more completely.

text: THEN YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT YOU'RE TALKING ABOUT
translated_text: Then you don't know what you're talking about.

text: YES I KNOW VERY WELL
translated_text: Yes, I know very well.

text: ALEXANDER FLUSHED ANGRILY
translated_text: Alexander flushed angrily.

text: I DON'T KNOW WHAT I OUGHT TO SAY BUT I DON'T BELIEVE YOU'D BE HAPPY TRULY I DON'T AREN'T YOU TRYING TO FRIGHTEN ME
translated_text: I don't know what I ought to say, but I don't believe you'd be happy, truly I don't. Aren't you trying to frighten me?

text: A LAUDABLE REGARD FOR THE HONOR OF THE FIRST PROSELYTE HAS COUNTENANCED THE BELIEF THE HOPE THE WISH THAT THE EBIONITES OR AT LEAST THE NAZARENES WERE DISTINGUISHED ONLY BY THEIR OBSTINATE PERSEVERANCE IN THE PRACTICE OF THE MOSAIC RITES
translated_text: A laudable regard for the honor of the First Prozolite has countenst the belief, the hope, the wish, that the Ebionites, or at least the Nazarens, were distinguished only by their opposite perseverance in the practice of the Mosaic rights.

text: THEIR CHURCHES HAVE DISAPPEARED THEIR BOOKS ARE OBLITERATED THEIR OBSCURE FREEDOM MIGHT ALLOW A LATITUDE OF FAITH AND THE SOFTNESS OF THEIR INFANT CREED WOULD BE VARIOUSLY MOULDED BY THE ZEAL OR PRUDENCE OF THREE HUNDRED YEARS
translated_text: Their churches have disappeared, their books are obliterated, their obscure freedom might allow a latitude of faith, and the softness of their infant creed would be variously molded by the zeal or prudence of 300 years.

text: YET THE MOST CHARITABLE CRITICISM MUST REFUSE THESE SECTARIES ANY KNOWLEDGE OF THE PURE AND PROPER DIVINITY OF CHRIST
translated_text: Yet the most charitable criticism must refuse these sectaries any knowledge of the pure and proper divinity of Christ.

text: HIS PROGRESS FROM INFANCY TO YOUTH AND MANHOOD WAS MARKED BY A REGULAR INCREASE IN STATURE AND WISDOM AND AFTER A PAINFUL AGONY OF MIND AND BODY HE EXPIRED ON THE CROSS
translated_text: His progress from infancy to youth and manhood was marked by a regular increase in stature and wisdom, and after a painful agony of mind and body, he expired on the cross.

text: HE LIVED AND DIED FOR THE SERVICE OF MANKIND BUT THE LIFE AND DEATH OF SOCRATES HAD LIKEWISE BEEN DEVOTED TO THE CAUSE OF RELIGION AND JUSTICE AND ALTHOUGH THE STOIC OR THE HERO MAY DISDAIN THE HUMBLE VIRTUES OF JESUS THE TEARS WHICH HE SHED OVER HIS FRIEND AND COUNTRY MAY BE ESTEEMED THE PUREST EVIDENCE OF HIS HUMANITY
translated_text: He lived and died for the service of mankind, but the life and death of Socrates had likewise been devoted to the cause of religion and justice, and although the stoic or the hero may disdain the humble virtues of Jesus, the tears which he shed over his friend and country may be esteemed the purest evidence of his humanity.

text: THE SON OF A VIRGIN GENERATED BY THE INEFFABLE OPERATION OF THE HOLY SPIRIT WAS A CREATURE WITHOUT EXAMPLE OR RESEMBLANCE SUPERIOR IN EVERY ATTRIBUTE OF MIND AND BODY TO THE CHILDREN OF ADAM
translated_text: The son of a virgin, generated by the ineffable operation of the Holy Spirit, was a creature without example or resemblance, superior in every attribute of mind and body to the children of Adam.

text: NOR COULD IT SEEM STRANGE OR INCREDIBLE THAT THE FIRST OF THESE AEONS THE LOGOS OR WORD OF GOD OF THE SAME SUBSTANCE WITH THE FATHER SHOULD DESCEND UPON EARTH TO DELIVER THE HUMAN RACE FROM VICE AND ERROR AND TO CONDUCT THEM IN THE PATHS OF LIFE AND IMMORTALITY
translated_text: Nor could it seem strange or incredible that the first of these eons, the Logos, or Word of God, of the same substance with the Father, should descend upon earth to deliver the human race from vice and error, and to conduct them in the paths of life and immortality.

text: BUT THE PREVAILING DOCTRINE OF THE ETERNITY AND INHERENT PRAVITY OF MATTER INFECTED THE PRIMITIVE CHURCHES OF THE EAST
translated_text: But the prevailing doctrine of the eternity and inherent gravity of matter infected the primitive churches of the east.

text: MANY AMONG THE GENTILE PROSELYTES REFUSED TO BELIEVE THAT A CELESTIAL SPIRIT AN UNDIVIDED PORTION OF THE FIRST ESSENCE HAD BEEN PERSONALLY UNITED WITH A MASS OF IMPURE AND CONTAMINATED FLESH AND IN THEIR ZEAL FOR THE DIVINITY THEY PIOUSLY ABJURED THE HUMANITY OF CHRIST
translated_text: Many among the Gentile presulites refused to believe that a celestial spirit, an undivided portion of the first essence, had been personally united with a mass of impure and contaminated flesh, and in their zeal for the divinity, they piously absurd the humanity of Christ.

text: HE FIRST APPEARED ON THE BANKS OF THE JORDAN IN THE FORM OF PERFECT MANHOOD BUT IT WAS A FORM ONLY AND NOT A SUBSTANCE A HUMAN FIGURE CREATED BY THE HAND OF OMNIPOTENCE TO IMITATE THE FACULTIES AND ACTIONS OF A MAN AND TO IMPOSE A PERPETUAL ILLUSION ON THE SENSES OF HIS FRIENDS AND ENEMIES
translated_text: He first appeared on the banks of the Jordan in the form of perfect manhood, but it was a form only, and not a substance, a human figure created by the hand of omnipotence to imitate the faculties and actions of a man, and to impose a perpetual illusion on the senses of his friends and enemies.

text: BUT THE RASHNESS OF THESE CONCESSIONS HAS ENCOURAGED A MILDER SENTIMENT OF THOSE OF THE DOCETES WHO TAUGHT NOT THAT CHRIST WAS A PHANTOM BUT THAT HE WAS CLOTHED WITH AN IMPASSIBLE AND INCORRUPTIBLE BODY
translated_text: But the rashness of these concessions has encouraged a milder sentiment of those of the dosi, who taught not that Christ was a phantom, but that he was clothed with an impassable and incorruptible body.

text: A FOETUS THAT COULD INCREASE FROM AN INVISIBLE POINT TO ITS FULL MATURITY A CHILD THAT COULD ATTAIN THE STATURE OF PERFECT MANHOOD WITHOUT DERIVING ANY NOURISHMENT FROM THE ORDINARY SOURCES MIGHT CONTINUE TO EXIST WITHOUT REPAIRING A DAILY WASTE BY A DAILY SUPPLY OF EXTERNAL MATTER
translated_text: A fetus that could increase from an invisible point to its full maturity, a child that could attain the stature of perfect madhood without deriving any nourishment from the ordinary sources, might continue to exist without repairing a daily waste by a daily supply of external matter.

text: IN THEIR EYES JESUS OF NAZARETH WAS A MERE MORTAL THE LEGITIMATE SON OF JOSEPH AND MARY BUT HE WAS THE BEST AND WISEST OF THE HUMAN RACE SELECTED AS THE WORTHY INSTRUMENT TO RESTORE UPON EARTH THE WORSHIP OF THE TRUE AND SUPREME DEITY
translated_text: In their eyes, Jesus of Nazareth was a mere mortal. The legitimate son of Joseph and Mary, but he was the best and wisest of the human race, selected as the worthy instruments to restore upon earth the worship of the true and supreme deity.

text: WHEN THE MESSIAH WAS DELIVERED INTO THE HANDS OF THE JEWS THE CHRIST AN IMMORTAL AND IMPASSIBLE BEING FORSOOK HIS EARTHLY TABERNACLE FLEW BACK TO THE PLEROMA OR WORLD OF SPIRITS AND LEFT THE SOLITARY JESUS TO SUFFER TO COMPLAIN AND TO EXPIRE
translated_text: When the Messiah was delivered into the hands of the Jews, the Christ and immortal and impassable being for sook his earthly tabernacle flew back to the plerima or world of spirits and left the solitary Jesus to suffer, to complain, and to expire.

text: BUT THE JUSTICE AND GENEROSITY OF SUCH A DESERTION ARE STRONGLY QUESTIONABLE AND THE FATE OF AN INNOCENT MARTYR AT FIRST IMPELLED AND AT LENGTH ABANDONED BY HIS DIVINE COMPANION MIGHT PROVOKE THE PITY AND INDIGNATION OF THE PROFANE
translated_text: But the justice and generosity of such a desertion are strongly questionable, and the fate of an innocent martyr at first impelled and at length abandoned by his divine companion might provoke the pity and indignation of the profane.

text: THEIR MURMURS WERE VARIOUSLY SILENCED BY THE SECTARIES WHO ESPOUSED AND MODIFIED THE DOUBLE SYSTEM OF CERINTHUS
translated_text: Their murmurs were variously silenced by the sectaries who espoused and modified the double system of Corinthus.

text: THE WORTHY FRIEND OF ATHANASIUS THE WORTHY ANTAGONIST OF JULIAN HE BRAVELY WRESTLED WITH THE ARIANS AND POLYTHEISTS AND THOUGH HE AFFECTED THE RIGOR OF GEOMETRICAL DEMONSTRATION HIS COMMENTARIES REVEALED THE LITERAL AND ALLEGORICAL SENSE OF THE SCRIPTURES
translated_text: The worthy friend of Athanasius, the worthy antagonist of Julian, he bravely wrestled with the Aryans and polytheists, and though he affected the rigor of geometrical demonstration, his commentaries revealed the literal and allegorical sense of the scriptures.

text: YET AS THE PROFOUND DOCTOR HAD BEEN TERRIFIED AT HIS OWN RASHNESS APOLLINARIS WAS HEARD TO MUTTER SOME FAINT ACCENTS OF EXCUSE AND EXPLANATION
translated_text: Yet, as the profound doctor had been terrified of his own rationalist, a Polinaris was heard to mutter some faint accents of excuse and explanation.

text: HE ACQUIESCED IN THE OLD DISTINCTION OF THE GREEK PHILOSOPHERS BETWEEN THE RATIONAL AND SENSITIVE SOUL OF MAN THAT HE MIGHT RESERVE THE LOGOS FOR INTELLECTUAL FUNCTIONS AND EMPLOY THE SUBORDINATE HUMAN PRINCIPLE IN THE MEANER ACTIONS OF ANIMAL LIFE
translated_text: He acquiesced in the old distinction of the Greek philosopher as between the rational and sensitive soul of man, that he might reserve the logos for intellectual functions and employ the subordinate human principle in the meaner actions of animal life.

text: BUT INSTEAD OF A TEMPORARY AND OCCASIONAL ALLIANCE THEY ESTABLISHED AND WE STILL EMBRACE THE SUBSTANTIAL INDISSOLUBLE AND EVERLASTING UNION OF A PERFECT GOD WITH A PERFECT MAN OF THE SECOND PERSON OF THE TRINITY WITH A REASONABLE SOUL AND HUMAN FLESH
translated_text: But instead of a temporary and occasional alliance, they established and we seal embrace the substantial, indesoluble and everlasting union of a perfect God with a perfect man, of the second person of the Trinity with a reasonable soul and human flesh.

text: UNDER THE TUITION OF THE ABBOT SERAPION HE APPLIED HIMSELF TO ECCLESIASTICAL STUDIES WITH SUCH INDEFATIGABLE ARDOR THAT IN THE COURSE OF ONE SLEEPLESS NIGHT HE HAS PERUSED THE FOUR GOSPELS THE CATHOLIC EPISTLES AND THE EPISTLE TO THE ROMANS
translated_text: Under the tuition of the Abbott Serapian, he applied himself to ecclesiastical studies with such indefatigable order that in the course of one sleepless night he has perused the four gospels, the Catholic epistles, and the epistles of the Romans.

text: ARDENT IN THE PROSECUTION OF HERESY CYRIL AUSPICIOUSLY OPENED HIS REIGN BY OPPRESSING THE NOVATIANS THE MOST INNOCENT AND HARMLESS OF THE SECTARIES
translated_text: ardent in the prosecution of heresy, Carol auspiciously opened his reign by oppressing the novations, the most innocent and harmless of the sectaries.

text: WITHOUT ANY LEGAL SENTENCE WITHOUT ANY ROYAL MANDATE THE PATRIARCH AT THE DAWN OF DAY LED A SEDITIOUS MULTITUDE TO THE ATTACK OF THE SYNAGOGUES
translated_text: Without any legal sentence, without any royal mandate, the patriarch at the dawn of the day led a seditious multitude to the attack of the synagogues.

text: SUCH CRIMES WOULD HAVE DESERVED THE ANIMADVERSION OF THE MAGISTRATE BUT IN THIS PROMISCUOUS OUTRAGE THE INNOCENT WERE CONFOUNDED WITH THE GUILTY AND ALEXANDRIA WAS IMPOVERISHED BY THE LOSS OF A WEALTHY AND INDUSTRIOUS COLONY
translated_text: Such crimes would have deserved the animate version of the magistrate, but in this promiscuous outrage, the innocent were confounded with the guilty, and Alexandria was impoverished by the loss of a wealthy and industrious colony.

text: THE ZEAL OF CYRIL EXPOSED HIM TO THE PENALTIES OF THE JULIAN LAW BUT IN A FEEBLE GOVERNMENT AND A SUPERSTITIOUS AGE HE WAS SECURE OF IMPUNITY AND EVEN OF PRAISE
translated_text: The zeal of Carol exposed him to the penalties of the Julian Law, but in a feeble government and a superstitious age, he was secure of impunity and even of praise.

text: ORESTES COMPLAINED BUT HIS JUST COMPLAINTS WERE TOO QUICKLY FORGOTTEN BY THE MINISTERS OF THEODOSIUS AND TOO DEEPLY REMEMBERED BY A PRIEST WHO AFFECTED TO PARDON AND CONTINUED TO HATE THE PRAEFECT OF EGYPT
translated_text: Oresti is complained, but his just complaints were too quickly forgotten by the ministers of theodosius, and too deeply remembered by a priest who affected the pardon and continued to hate the prefective Egypt.

text: A RUMOR WAS SPREAD AMONG THE CHRISTIANS THAT THE DAUGHTER OF THEON WAS THE ONLY OBSTACLE TO THE RECONCILIATION OF THE PRAEFECT AND THE ARCHBISHOP AND THAT OBSTACLE WAS SPEEDILY REMOVED
translated_text: A rumor was spread among the Christians that the daughter of Theon was the only obstacle to the reconciliation of the prefect in the Archbishop, and that obstacle was spedily removed.

text: WHICH OPPRESSED THE METROPOLITANS OF EUROPE AND ASIA INVADED THE PROVINCES OF ANTIOCH AND ALEXANDRIA AND MEASURED THEIR DIOCESE BY THE LIMITS OF THE EMPIRE
translated_text: which oppressed the metropolitan of Europe and Asia, invaded the provinces of Antioch and Alexandria, and measured their diocese by the limits of the Empire.

text: EXTERMINATE WITH ME THE HERETICS AND WITH YOU I WILL EXTERMINATE THE PERSIANS
translated_text: exterminate with me the heretics and with you I will exterminate the Persians.

text: AT THESE BLASPHEMOUS SOUNDS THE PILLARS OF THE SANCTUARY WERE SHAKEN
translated_text: At these blasts from a sound, the pillars of the sanctuary were shaken.

text: BUT THE VATICAN RECEIVED WITH OPEN ARMS THE MESSENGERS OF EGYPT
translated_text: but the Vatican received with open arms the messengers of Egypt.

text: THE VANITY OF CELESTINE WAS FLATTERED BY THE APPEAL AND THE PARTIAL VERSION OF A MONK DECIDED THE FAITH OF THE POPE WHO WITH HIS LATIN CLERGY WAS IGNORANT OF THE LANGUAGE THE ARTS AND THE THEOLOGY OF THE GREEKS
translated_text: The vanity of Kellestine was flattered by the appeal, and the partial version of a monk decided the faith of the Pope, who with his Latin clergy was ignorant of the language, the arts, and the theology of the Greeks.

text: NESTORIUS WHO DEPENDED ON THE NEAR APPROACH OF HIS EASTERN FRIENDS PERSISTED LIKE HIS PREDECESSOR CHRYSOSTOM TO DISCLAIM THE JURISDICTION AND TO DISOBEY THE SUMMONS OF HIS ENEMIES THEY HASTENED HIS TRIAL AND HIS ACCUSER PRESIDED IN THE SEAT OF JUDGMENT
translated_text: Nistorius, who depended on the near approach of his Eastern friends, persisted, like his predecessor Chrysostom, to disclaim the jurisdiction and to disobey the summons of his enemies. They hastened his trial, and his accuser presided in the seat of judgment.

text: SIXTY EIGHT BISHOPS TWENTY TWO OF METROPOLITAN RANK DEFENDED HIS CAUSE BY A MODEST AND TEMPERATE PROTEST THEY WERE EXCLUDED FROM THE COUNCILS OF THEIR BRETHREN
translated_text: 68 bishops, 22 of Metropolitan Rank, defended his cause by a modest and temperate protest. They were excluded from the councils of their brethren.

text: BY THE VIGILANCE OF MEMNON THE CHURCHES WERE SHUT AGAINST THEM AND A STRONG GARRISON WAS THROWN INTO THE CATHEDRAL
translated_text: By the vigilance of Memnon, the churches were shot against them, and a strong garrison was thrown into the cathedral.

text: DURING A BUSY PERIOD OF THREE MONTHS THE EMPEROR TRIED EVERY METHOD EXCEPT THE MOST EFFECTUAL MEANS OF INDIFFERENCE AND CONTEMPT TO RECONCILE THIS THEOLOGICAL QUARREL
translated_text: During a busy period of three months, the Emperor tried every method except the most effectual means of indifference and contempt to reconcile this theological quarrel.

text: RETURN TO YOUR PROVINCES AND MAY YOUR PRIVATE VIRTUES REPAIR THE MISCHIEF AND SCANDAL OF YOUR MEETING
translated_text: Return to your provinces and pay your private virtues repair the mischief and scandal of your meeting.

text: THE FEEBLE SON OF ARCADIUS WAS ALTERNATELY SWAYED BY HIS WIFE AND SISTER BY THE EUNUCHS AND WOMEN OF THE PALACE SUPERSTITION AND AVARICE WERE THEIR RULING PASSIONS AND THE ORTHODOX CHIEFS WERE ASSIDUOUS IN THEIR ENDEAVORS TO ALARM THE FORMER AND TO GRATIFY THE LATTER
translated_text: The feeble son of Arcadiaus was alternately swayed by his wife and sister, by the unix and women of the palace. Supercision and averse were their ruling passions, and the Orthodox chiefs were asidious in their endeavors to alarm the former and to gratify the latter.

text: BUT IN THIS AWFUL MOMENT OF THE DANGER OF THE CHURCH THEIR VOW WAS SUPERSEDED BY A MORE SUBLIME AND INDISPENSABLE DUTY
translated_text: But in this awful moment of the danger of the church, their vow was superseded by a more sublime and indispensable duty.

text: AT THE SAME TIME EVERY AVENUE OF THE THRONE WAS ASSAULTED WITH GOLD
translated_text: At the same time, every avenue of the throne was assaulted with gold.

text: THE PAST HE REGRETTED HE WAS DISCONTENTED WITH THE PRESENT AND THE FUTURE HE HAD REASON TO DREAD THE ORIENTAL BISHOPS SUCCESSIVELY DISENGAGED THEIR CAUSE FROM HIS UNPOPULAR NAME AND EACH DAY DECREASED THE NUMBER OF THE SCHISMATICS WHO REVERED NESTORIUS AS THE CONFESSOR OF THE FAITH
translated_text: The past he regretted. He was discontented with the present, and the future he had reason to dread. The Oriental bishops, successively, disengaged their cause from his unpopular name, and each day decreased the number of the schismatics who revered Nostoreus as the confessor of the faith.

text: A WANDERING TRIBE OF THE BLEMMYES OR NUBIANS INVADED HIS SOLITARY PRISON IN THEIR RETREAT THEY DISMISSED A CROWD OF USELESS CAPTIVES BUT NO SOONER HAD NESTORIUS REACHED THE BANKS OF THE NILE THAN HE WOULD GLADLY HAVE ESCAPED FROM A ROMAN AND ORTHODOX CITY TO THE MILDER SERVITUDE OF THE SAVAGES
translated_text: A wandering tribe of the Blemais or Nubians invaded his solitary prison. In their retreat, they dismissed a crowd of useless captives, but no sooner had Nisterius reached the banks of the Nile than he would gladly have escaped from a Roman and orthodox city to the milder servitude of the savages.

text: HE HAD NEVER BEEN FATHER LOVER HUSBAND FRIEND
translated_text: He had never been father, lover, husband, friend.

text: THE HEART OF THAT EX CONVICT WAS FULL OF VIRGINITY
translated_text: The heart of that exconvict was full of virginity.

text: HIS SISTER AND HIS SISTER'S CHILDREN HAD LEFT HIM ONLY A VAGUE AND FAR OFF MEMORY WHICH HAD FINALLY ALMOST COMPLETELY VANISHED HE HAD MADE EVERY EFFORT TO FIND THEM AND NOT HAVING BEEN ABLE TO FIND THEM HE HAD FORGOTTEN THEM
translated_text: His sister and his sister's children had left him only a vague and far-off memory, which had finally almost completely vanished. He had made every effort to find them, and not having been able to find them, he had forgotten them.

text: HE SUFFERED ALL THE PANGS OF A MOTHER AND HE KNEW NOT WHAT IT MEANT FOR THAT GREAT AND SINGULAR MOVEMENT OF A HEART WHICH BEGINS TO LOVE IS A VERY OBSCURE AND A VERY SWEET THING
translated_text: He suffered all the pangs of a mother, and he knew not what it meant. For that great and singular movement of a heart which begins to love is a very obscure and a very sweet thing.

text: ONLY AS HE WAS FIVE AND FIFTY AND COSETTE EIGHT YEARS OF AGE ALL THAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN LOVE IN THE WHOLE COURSE OF HIS LIFE FLOWED TOGETHER INTO A SORT OF INEFFABLE LIGHT
translated_text: Only as he was five and fifty, and co-zete eight years of age, all that might have been love in the whole course of his life flowed together into a sort of ineffable light.

text: COSETTE ON HER SIDE HAD ALSO UNKNOWN TO HERSELF BECOME ANOTHER BEING POOR LITTLE THING
translated_text: Kosech, on her side, had also, unknown to herself, become another being. Poor little thing.

text: SHE FELT THAT WHICH SHE HAD NEVER FELT BEFORE A SENSATION OF EXPANSION
translated_text: She felt that which she had never felt before. A sensation of expansion.

text: THE MAN NO LONGER PRODUCED ON HER THE EFFECT OF BEING OLD OR POOR SHE THOUGHT JEAN VALJEAN HANDSOME JUST AS SHE THOUGHT THE HOVEL PRETTY
translated_text: The man no longer produced on her the effect of being old or poor. She thought Jean-Faussion handsome, just as she thought the Hubble pretty.

text: NATURE A DIFFERENCE OF FIFTY YEARS HAD SET A PROFOUND GULF BETWEEN JEAN VALJEAN AND COSETTE DESTINY FILLED IN THIS GULF
translated_text: Nature, a difference of fifty years, had set a profound gulf between Jean-Fauljon and Cousette. Destiny filled in this gulf.

text: TO MEET WAS TO FIND EACH OTHER
translated_text: To meet was to find each other.

text: WHEN THESE TWO SOULS PERCEIVED EACH OTHER THEY RECOGNIZED EACH OTHER AS NECESSARY TO EACH OTHER AND EMBRACED EACH OTHER CLOSELY
translated_text: When these two souls perceive each other, they recognize each other as necessary to each other, and embrace each other closely.

text: MOREOVER JEAN VALJEAN HAD CHOSEN HIS REFUGE WELL
translated_text: Moreover, Sean Valchon had chosen his refuge well.

text: HE HAD PAID HER SIX MONTHS IN ADVANCE AND HAD COMMISSIONED THE OLD WOMAN TO FURNISH THE CHAMBER AND DRESSING ROOM AS WE HAVE SEEN
translated_text: He had paid her six months in advance and had commissioned the old woman to furnish the chamber and dressing room as we have seen.

text: WEEK FOLLOWED WEEK THESE TWO BEINGS LED A HAPPY LIFE IN THAT HOVEL
translated_text: Week followed week. These two beings led a happy life in that Hubble.

text: COSETTE WAS NO LONGER IN RAGS SHE WAS IN MOURNING
translated_text: Kusek was no longer in rags. She was in mourning.

text: AND THEN HE TALKED OF HER MOTHER AND HE MADE HER PRAY
translated_text: And then he talked to her mother and he made her pray.

text: HE PASSED HOURS IN WATCHING HER DRESSING AND UNDRESSING HER DOLL AND IN LISTENING TO HER PRATTLE
translated_text: He passed hours in watching her dressing and undressing her doll, and it listening to her prowl.

text: THE BEST OF US ARE NOT EXEMPT FROM EGOTISTICAL THOUGHTS
translated_text: The best of us are not exempt from egotistical thoughts.

text: HE HAD RETURNED TO PRISON THIS TIME FOR HAVING DONE RIGHT HE HAD QUAFFED FRESH BITTERNESS DISGUST AND LASSITUDE WERE OVERPOWERING HIM EVEN THE MEMORY OF THE BISHOP PROBABLY SUFFERED A TEMPORARY ECLIPSE THOUGH SURE TO REAPPEAR LATER ON LUMINOUS AND TRIUMPHANT BUT AFTER ALL THAT SACRED MEMORY WAS GROWING DIM
translated_text: He had returned to prison, this time for having done right. He had quaffed fresh bitterness. Disgust and lassitude were overpowering him. Even the memory of the bishop probably suffered a temporary eclipse, though short to reappear later on, luminous and triumphant. But after all, that sacred memory was growing dim.

text: WHO KNOWS WHETHER JEAN VALJEAN HAD NOT BEEN ON THE EVE OF GROWING DISCOURAGED AND OF FALLING ONCE MORE
translated_text: Who knows, with her Jean-Fauljant, had not been on the eve of growing discouraged and of falling once more?

text: ALAS HE WALKED WITH NO LESS INDECISION THAN COSETTE
translated_text: He'll ask, he walked with no less indecision than Kozet.

text: HE PROTECTED HER AND SHE STRENGTHENED HIM
translated_text: He protected her, and she strengthened him.

text: HE WAS THAT CHILD'S STAY AND SHE WAS HIS PROP
translated_text: He was that child's day, and she was his prop.

text: FORGOTTEN TOO THE NAME OF GILLIAN THE LOVELY CAPTIVE
translated_text: Forgotten two, the name of Gillian, the lovely captive.

text: WORSE AND WORSE HE IS EVEN PRESUMED TO BE THE CAPTIVE'S SWEETHEART WHO WHEEDLES THE FLOWER THE RING AND THE PRISON KEY OUT OF THE STRICT VIRGINS FOR HIS OWN PURPOSES AND FLIES WITH HER AT LAST IN HIS SHALLOP ACROSS THE SEA TO LIVE WITH HER HAPPILY EVER AFTER
translated_text: Worsen, worse, he is even presumed to be the cat of sweetheart, who weedles the flower, the ring, and the prison key out of the strict furchions for his own purposes, and flies with her at last in a shallow across the sea, to live with her happily ever after.

text: BUT THIS IS A FALLACY
translated_text: But this is a fallacy.

text: THE WANDERING SINGER APPROACHES THEM WITH HIS LUTE
translated_text: The wandering singer approaches them with his loot.

text: THE EMPEROR'S DAUGHTER
translated_text: The Emperor's Daughter.

text: LADY LADY MY ROSE WHITE LADY BUT WILL YOU NOT HEAR A ROUNDEL LADY
translated_text: Lady, lady, my rose white lady, but will you not hear around a lady?

text: O IF YOU PLAY US A ROUNDEL SINGER HOW CAN THAT HARM THE EMPEROR'S DAUGHTER
translated_text: Oh, if you play us a roundel singer, how can that harm the Emperor's daughter?

text: SHE WOULD NOT SPEAK THOUGH WE DANCED A WEEK WITH HER THOUGHTS A THOUSAND LEAGUES OVER THE WATER SINGER SINGER WANDERING SINGER O MY HONEY SWEET SINGER
translated_text: She would not speak that we danced o'keek, with her thoughts a thousand leagues over the water. Singer, singer, wandering singer, oh my honey sweet singer.

text: BUT IF I PLAY YOU A ROUNDEL LADY GET ME A GIFT FROM THE EMPEROR'S DAUGHTER HER FINGER RING FOR MY FINGER BRING THOUGH SHE'S PLEDGED A THOUSAND LEAGUES OVER THE WATER LADY LADY MY FAIR LADY O MY ROSE WHITE LADY
translated_text: But if I play you a round old lady, get me a gift from the Emperor's daughter. Her finger ring for my finger ring, though she's pledged a thousand leagues over the water. Lady, lady, my fair lady. Oh, my rose white lady.

text: THE WANDERING SINGER
translated_text: The Wandering Singer.

text: BUT I DID ONCE HAVE THE LUCK TO HEAR AND SEE THE LADY PLAYED IN ENTIRETY THE CHILDREN HAD BEEN GRANTED LEAVE TO PLAY JUST ONE MORE GAME BEFORE BED TIME AND OF COURSE THEY CHOSE THE LONGEST AND PLAYED IT WITHOUT MISSING A SYLLABLE
translated_text: But I did once have the luck to hear and see the lady played an entirety. The children had been granted leave to play just one more game before bedtime. And of course, they chose the longest and played it without missing a syllable.

text: THE LADIES IN YELLOW DRESSES STAND AGAIN IN A RING ABOUT THE EMPEROR'S DAUGHTER AND ARE FOR THE LAST TIME ACCOSTED BY THE SINGER WITH HIS LUTE
translated_text: The ladies, in yellow dresses, stand again in a ring about the Emperor's daughter, and are for the last time accosted by the singer with his loot.

text: THE WANDERING SINGER
translated_text: The Wandering Singer.

text: I'LL PLAY FOR YOU NOW NEATH THE APPLE BOUGH AND YOU SHALL DREAM ON THE LAWN SO SHADY LADY LADY MY FAIR LADY O MY APPLE GOLD LADY
translated_text: I'll play for you now, Nithy Apple Bow, and you shall dream on the lawn so shady. Lady, lady, my fair lady, oh my Apple Gold Lady.

text: THE LADIES
translated_text: The ladies.

text: NOW YOU MAY PLAY A SERENA SINGER A DREAM OF NIGHT FOR AN APPLE GOLD LADY FOR THE FRUIT IS NOW ON THE APPLE BOUGH AND THE MOON IS UP AND THE LAWN IS SHADY SINGER SINGER WANDERING SINGER O MY HONEY SWEET SINGER
translated_text: Now you may play a serena singer, a dream of night for an apple gold lady, for the fruit is now on the apple bow, and the moon is up and the lawn is shady. Singer, singer, wandering singer, oh my honey sweet singer!

text: ONCE MORE THE SINGER PLAYS AND THE LADIES DANCE BUT ONE BY ONE THEY FALL ASLEEP TO THE DROWSY MUSIC AND THEN THE SINGER STEPS INTO THE RING AND UNLOCKS THE TOWER AND KISSES THE EMPEROR'S DAUGHTER
translated_text: Once more, the singer plays in the ladies' dance. But one by one, they fall asleep to the drowsy music, and then the singer steps into the ring, and unlocks the tower and kisses the Emperor's daughter.

text: I DON'T KNOW WHAT BECOMES OF THE LADIES
translated_text: I don't know what becomes of the ladies.

text: BED TIME CHILDREN
translated_text: Bedtime children.

text: YOU SEE THE TREATMENT IS A TRIFLE FANCIFUL
translated_text: You see, the treatment is a trifle fanciful.

text: HOW WE MUST SIMPLIFY
translated_text: How we must simplify.

text: IT SEEMS TO ME MORE AND MORE AS I LIVE LONGER THAT MOST POETRY AND MOST LITERATURE AND PARTICULARLY THE LITERATURE OF THE PAST IS DISCORDANT WITH THE VASTNESS AND VARIETY THE RESERVES AND RESOURCES AND RECUPERATIONS OF LIFE AS WE LIVE IT TO DAY
translated_text: It seems to me more and more as I live longer. The most poetry and most literature, and particularly the literature of the past, is discordant with the vastness and variety, the reserves and resources and recuperations of life as we live it today.

text: IT IS THE EXPRESSION OF LIFE UNDER CRUDER AND MORE RIGID CONDITIONS THAN OURS LIVED BY PEOPLE WHO LOVED AND HATED MORE NAIVELY AGED SOONER AND DIED YOUNGER THAN WE DO
translated_text: It is the expression of life under cruder and more rigid conditions than ours, lived by people who loved and hated more naïvely, aged sooner and died younger than we do.

text: WE RANGE WIDER LAST LONGER AND ESCAPE MORE AND MORE FROM INTENSITY TOWARDS UNDERSTANDING
translated_text: We range wider, last longer, and escape more and more from intensity towards understanding.

text: AND ALREADY THIS ASTOUNDING BLOW BEGINS TO TAKE ITS PLACE AMONG OTHER EVENTS AS A THING STRANGE AND TERRIBLE INDEED BUT RELATED TO ALL THE STRANGENESS AND MYSTERY OF LIFE PART OF THE UNIVERSAL MYSTERIES OF DESPAIR AND FUTILITY AND DEATH THAT HAVE TROUBLED MY CONSCIOUSNESS SINCE CHILDHOOD
translated_text: And already, this astounding blow begins to take its place among other events, as a thing strange and terrible indeed, but related to all the strangeness and mystery of life, part of the universal mysteries of despair and futility and death that have troubled my consciousness since childhood.

text: FOR A TIME THE DEATH OF MARY OBSCURED HER LIFE FOR ME BUT NOW HER LIVING PRESENCE IS MORE IN MY MIND AGAIN
translated_text: For a time, the death of Mary obscured her life for me. But now her living presence is more in my mind again.

text: IT WAS THAT IDEA OF WASTE THAT DOMINATED MY MIND IN A STRANGE INTERVIEW I HAD WITH JUSTIN
translated_text: It was that idea of waste that dominated my mind, in a strange interview I had with Justin.

text: I BECAME GROTESQUELY ANXIOUS TO ASSURE HIM THAT INDEED SHE AND I HAD BEEN AS THEY SAY INNOCENT THROUGHOUT OUR LAST DAY TOGETHER
translated_text: I became grotesquely anxious to assure him that indeed she and I had been, as they say, innocent throughout her last day together.

text: YOU WERE WRONG IN ALL THAT I SAID SHE KEPT HER FAITH WITH YOU
translated_text: You were wrong in all that. I said, she kept her faith with you.

text: WE NEVER PLANNED TO MEET AND WHEN WE MET
translated_text: We never planned to meet and when we met.

text: IF WE HAD BEEN BROTHER AND SISTER INDEED THERE WAS NOTHING
translated_text: If we had been brother and sister, indeed there was nothing.

text: BUT NOW IT DOESN'T SEEM TO MATTER VERY MUCH
translated_text: But now it doesn't seem to matter very much.

text: AND IT IS UPON THIS EFFECT OF SWEET AND BEAUTIFUL POSSIBILITIES CAUGHT IN THE NET OF ANIMAL JEALOUSIES AND THOUGHTLESS MOTIVES AND ANCIENT RIGID INSTITUTIONS THAT I WOULD END THIS WRITING
translated_text: And it is upon this effect of sweet and beautiful possibilities caught in the net of animal jealousies and thoughtless motives and ancient rigid institutions that I would end this writing.

text: IN MARY IT SEEMS TO ME I FOUND BOTH WOMANHOOD AND FELLOWSHIP I FOUND WHAT MANY HAVE DREAMT OF LOVE AND FRIENDSHIP FREELY GIVEN AND I COULD DO NOTHING BUT CLUTCH AT HER TO MAKE HER MY POSSESSION
translated_text: In Mary, it seems to me, I found both womanhood and fellowship. I found what many have dreamt of, love and friendship freely given. And I could do nothing but clutch at her to make her my possession.

text: WHAT ALTERNATIVE WAS THERE FOR HER
translated_text: What alternative was there for her?

text: SHE WAS DESTROYED NOT MERELY BY THE UNCONSIDERED UNDISCIPLINED PASSIONS OF HER HUSBAND AND HER LOVER BUT BY THE VAST TRADITION THAT SUSTAINS AND ENFORCES THE SUBJUGATION OF HER SEX
translated_text: She was destroyed, not merely by the unconsidered, undisciplined passions of her husband and her lover, but by the vast tradition that sustains and enforces the subjugation of her sex.

text: ILLUSTRATION LONG PEPPER
translated_text: Illustration, long pepper.

text: LONG PEPPER THIS IS THE PRODUCE OF A DIFFERENT PLANT FROM THAT WHICH PRODUCES THE BLACK IT CONSISTING OF THE HALF RIPE FLOWER HEADS OF WHAT NATURALISTS CALL PIPER LONGUM AND CHABA
translated_text: Long pepper. This is the produce of a different plant from that which produces the black. It consisting of the half ripe flower heads have what naturalists call Piper Longum and Chaba.

text: ORIGINALLY THE MOST VALUABLE OF THESE WERE FOUND IN THE SPICE ISLANDS OR MOLUCCAS OF THE INDIAN OCEAN AND WERE HIGHLY PRIZED BY THE NATIONS OF ANTIQUITY
translated_text: Originally, the most valuable of these were found in the Spice Islands or Maluchas of the Indian Ocean, and were highly prized by the nations of antiquity.

text: THE LONG PEPPER IS LESS AROMATIC THAN THE BLACK BUT ITS OIL IS MORE PUNGENT
translated_text: The long pepper is less aromatic than the black, but its oil is more pungent.

text: THEN ADD THE YOLKS OF THE EGGS WELL BEATEN STIR THEM TO THE SAUCE BUT DO NOT ALLOW IT TO BOIL AND SERVE VERY HOT
translated_text: Then add the yolks of the eggs well beaten. Stir them to the sauce, but do not allow it to boil and serve very hot.

text: MODE PARE AND SLICE THE CUCUMBERS AS FOR THE TABLE SPRINKLE WELL WITH SALT AND LET THEM REMAIN FOR TWENTY FOUR HOURS STRAIN OFF THE LIQUOR PACK IN JARS A THICK LAYER OF CUCUMBERS AND SALT ALTERNATELY TIE DOWN CLOSELY AND WHEN WANTED FOR USE TAKE OUT THE QUANTITY REQUIRED
translated_text: Mode. Pair and slice the cucumbers as for the table. Sprinkle well with salt and let them remain for 24 hours. Strain off the liquor, pack in jars, a thick layer of cucumbers and salt alternately. Tie down closely, and when wanted for use, take out the quantity required.

text: ILLUSTRATION THE CUCUMBER
translated_text: Illustration, the cucumber.

text: MODE CHOOSE THE GREENEST CUCUMBERS AND THOSE THAT ARE MOST FREE FROM SEEDS PUT THEM IN STRONG SALT AND WATER WITH A CABBAGE LEAF TO KEEP THEM DOWN TIE A PAPER OVER THEM AND PUT THEM IN A WARM PLACE TILL THEY ARE YELLOW THEN WASH THEM AND SET THEM OVER THE FIRE IN FRESH WATER WITH A VERY LITTLE SALT AND ANOTHER CABBAGE LEAF OVER THEM COVER VERY CLOSELY BUT TAKE CARE THEY DO NOT BOIL
translated_text: Mode. Choose the greenest cucumbers and those that are most free from seeds. Put them in strong salt and water with a cabbage leaf to keep them down. Tie a paper over them and put them in a warm place till they are yellow. Then wash them and set them over the fire in fresh water with a very little salt and another cabbage leaf over them. Cover very closely but take care they do not boil.

text: PUT THE SUGAR WITH ONE QUARTER PINT OF WATER IN A SAUCEPAN OVER THE FIRE REMOVE THE SCUM AS IT RISES AND ADD THE LEMON PEEL AND GINGER WITH THE OUTSIDE SCRAPED OFF WHEN THE SYRUP IS TOLERABLY THICK TAKE IT OFF THE FIRE AND WHEN COLD WIPE THE CUCUMBERS DRY AND PUT THEM IN
translated_text: Put the sugar with 1 ¼ pint of water in a saucepan over the fire. Remove the scum as it rises and add the lemon peel and ginger with the outside scraped off. When the syrup is tolerably thick, take it off the fire and when cold, wipe the cucumbers dry and put them in.

text: SEASONABLE THIS RECIPE SHOULD BE USED IN JUNE JULY OR AUGUST
translated_text: Seasonable. This recipe should be used in June, July or August.

text: SOLID ROCKS OF SALT ARE ALSO FOUND IN VARIOUS PARTS OF THE WORLD AND THE COUNTY OF CHESTER CONTAINS MANY OF THESE MINES AND IT IS FROM THERE THAT MUCH OF OUR SALT COMES
translated_text: Solid rocks of salt are also found in various parts of the world, and in the country of Chester contains many of these minds. And it is from there that much of our salt comes.

text: SOME SPRINGS ARE SO HIGHLY IMPREGNATED WITH SALT AS TO HAVE RECEIVED THE NAME OF BRINE SPRINGS AND ARE SUPPOSED TO HAVE BECOME SO BY PASSING THROUGH THE SALT ROCKS BELOW GROUND AND THUS DISSOLVING A PORTION OF THIS MINERAL SUBSTANCE
translated_text: Some springs are so highly impregnated with salt as to have received the name of brine springs, and are supposed to have become so by passing through the salt rocks below ground, and thus dissolving a portion of this mineral substance.

text: MODE PUT THE MILK IN A VERY CLEAN SAUCEPAN AND LET IT BOIL
translated_text: Mode. Put the milk in a very clean saucepan and let it boil.

text: BEAT THE EGGS STIR TO THEM THE MILK AND POUNDED SUGAR AND PUT THE MIXTURE INTO A JUG
translated_text: Beat the eggs, stir to them the milk and pounded sugar, and put the mixture into a jug.

text: PLACE THE JUG IN A SAUCEPAN OF BOILING WATER KEEP STIRRING WELL UNTIL IT THICKENS BUT DO NOT ALLOW IT TO BOIL OR IT WILL CURDLE
translated_text: Place the jug in a saucepan of boiling water. Keep stirring well until it thickens, but do not allow it to boil or it will curdle.

text: WHEN IT IS SUFFICIENTLY THICK TAKE IT OFF AS IT SHOULD NOT BOIL
translated_text: when it is sufficiently thick, take it off as it should not boil.

text: ILLUSTRATION THE LEMON
translated_text: Illustration, the lemon.

text: THE LEMON THIS FRUIT IS A NATIVE OF ASIA AND IS MENTIONED BY VIRGIL AS AN ANTIDOTE TO POISON
translated_text: The lemon. This fruit is a native of Asia and is mentioned by Virgil as an antidote to poison.

text: IT IS HARDIER THAN THE ORANGE AND AS ONE OF THE CITRON TRIBE WAS BROUGHT INTO EUROPE BY THE ARABIANS
translated_text: It is harder than the orange, and, as one of the Citron tribe, was brought into Europe by the Arabians.

text: THE LEMON WAS FIRST CULTIVATED IN ENGLAND IN THE BEGINNING OF THE SEVENTEENTH CENTURY AND IS NOW OFTEN TO BE FOUND IN OUR GREEN HOUSES
translated_text: The lemon was first cultivated in England in the beginning of the 17th century and is now often to be found in our greenhouses.

text: THIS JUICE WHICH IS CALLED CITRIC ACID MAY BE PRESERVED IN BOTTLES FOR A CONSIDERABLE TIME BY COVERING IT WITH A THIN STRATUM OF OIL
translated_text: This juice, which is called citric acid, may be preserved in bottles for a considerable time by covering it with a thin stratum of oil.

text: TO PICKLE EGGS
translated_text: to pickle eggs.

text: SEASONABLE THIS SHOULD BE MADE ABOUT EASTER AS AT THIS TIME EGGS ARE PLENTIFUL AND CHEAP
translated_text: Seasonable. This should be made about Easter as at this time eggs are plentiful and cheap.

text: A STORE OF PICKLED EGGS WILL BE FOUND VERY USEFUL AND ORNAMENTAL IN SERVING WITH MANY FIRST AND SECOND COURSE DISHES
translated_text: A store of pickled eggs will be found very useful and ornamental in serving with many first and second-course dishes.

text: ILLUSTRATION GINGER
translated_text: Illustration, Ginger.

text: THE GINGER PLANT KNOWN TO NATURALISTS AS ZINGIBER OFFICINALE IS A NATIVE OF THE EAST AND WEST INDIES
translated_text: The ginger plant, known to naturalists as Zingiber Officianale, is a native of the East and West Indies.

text: IN JAMAICA IT FLOWERS ABOUT AUGUST OR SEPTEMBER FADING ABOUT THE END OF THE YEAR
translated_text: In Jamaica, it flowers about August or September, fading about the end of the year.

text: BEAT THE YOLKS OF THE OTHER TWO EGGS ADD THEM WITH A LITTLE FLOUR AND SALT TO THOSE POUNDED MIX ALL WELL TOGETHER AND ROLL INTO BALLS
translated_text: Beat the yolks of the other two eggs, add them with a little flour and salt to those pounded. Mix all well together and roll into balls.

text: BOIL THEM BEFORE THEY ARE PUT INTO THE SOUP OR OTHER DISH THEY MAY BE INTENDED FOR
translated_text: Boil them before they are put into the soup or other dish they may be intended for.

text: LEMON JUICE MAY BE ADDED AT PLEASURE
translated_text: Lemon juice may be added at pleasure.

text: MODE PUT THE WHOLE OF THE INGREDIENTS INTO A BOTTLE AND LET IT REMAIN FOR A FORTNIGHT IN A WARM PLACE OCCASIONALLY SHAKING UP THE CONTENTS
translated_text: Mode. Put the hole of the ingredients into a bottle and let it remain for a fortnight in a warm place, occasionally shaking up the contents.

text: THEY OUGHT TO BE TAKEN UP IN THE AUTUMN AND WHEN DRIED IN THE HOUSE WILL KEEP TILL SPRING
translated_text: They ought to be taken up in the autumn, and when dried in the house will keep till spring.

text: ADD THE WINE AND IF NECESSARY A SEASONING OF CAYENNE WHEN IT WILL BE READY TO SERVE
translated_text: Add the wine and if necessary, a seasoning of cayenne when it will be ready to serve.

text: NOTE THE WINE IN THIS SAUCE MAY BE OMITTED AND AN ONION SLICED AND FRIED OF A NICE BROWN SUBSTITUTED FOR IT
translated_text: Note, the wine in this sauce may be omitted and an onion sliced and fried of a nice brown substituted for it.

text: SIMMER FOR A MINUTE OR TWO AND SERVE IN A TUREEN
translated_text: simmer for a minute or two and serve in a charine.

text: SUFFICIENT TO SERVE WITH FIVE OR SIX MACKEREL
translated_text: It's sufficient to serve with 5 or 6 macro.

text: VARIOUS DISHES ARE FREQUENTLY ORNAMENTED AND GARNISHED WITH ITS GRACEFUL LEAVES AND THESE ARE SOMETIMES BOILED IN SOUPS ALTHOUGH IT IS MORE USUALLY CONFINED IN ENGLISH COOKERY TO THE MACKEREL SAUCE AS HERE GIVEN
translated_text: Various dishes are frequently ornamented and garnished with its graceful leaves, and these are sometimes boiled in soups, although it is more usually confined in English cookery to the macro sauce as here given.

text: FORCEMEAT FOR COLD SAVOURY PIES
translated_text: Force meat for cold savory pies.

text: POUND WELL AND BIND WITH ONE OR TWO EGGS WHICH HAVE BEEN PREVIOUSLY BEATEN AND STRAINED
translated_text: pound well, and bind with one or two eggs, which have been previously beaten and strained.

text: ILLUSTRATION MARJORAM
translated_text: Illustration, Marjoram.

text: IT IS A NATIVE OF PORTUGAL AND WHEN ITS LEAVES ARE USED AS A SEASONING HERB THEY HAVE AN AGREEABLE AROMATIC FLAVOUR
translated_text: It is a native of Portugal, and when its leaves are used as a seasoning herb, they have an agreeable aromatic flavor.

text: MODE MIX ALL THE INGREDIENTS WELL TOGETHER CAREFULLY MINCING THEM VERY FINELY BEAT UP THE EGG MOISTEN WITH IT AND WORK THE WHOLE VERY SMOOTHLY TOGETHER
translated_text: Mode. Mix all the ingredients well together, carefully mincing them very finely. Beat up the egg, moisten with it, and work the whole very smoothly together.

text: SUFFICIENT FOR A MODERATE SIZED HADDOCK OR PIKE
translated_text: It's sufficient for a moderate size tadic or pike.

text: NOW BEAT AND STRAIN THE EGGS WORK THESE UP WITH THE OTHER INGREDIENTS AND THE FORCEMEAT WILL BE READY FOR USE
translated_text: Now beat and strain the eggs. Work these up with the other ingredients and the first meat will be ready for use.

text: BOIL FOR FIVE MINUTES MINCE IT VERY SMALL AND MIX IT WITH THE OTHER INGREDIENTS
translated_text: Boil for five minutes, mince it very small, and mix it with the other ingredients.

text: IF IT SHOULD BE IN AN UNSOUND STATE IT MUST BE ON NO ACCOUNT MADE USE OF
translated_text: If it should be in an unsound state, it must be on no account made use of.

text: ILLUSTRATION BASIL
translated_text: Illustration, Basil.

text: OTHER SWEET HERBS ARE CULTIVATED FOR PURPOSES OF MEDICINE AND PERFUMERY THEY ARE MOST GRATEFUL BOTH TO THE ORGANS OF TASTE AND SMELLING AND TO THE AROMA DERIVED FROM THEM IS DUE IN A GREAT MEASURE THE SWEET AND EXHILARATING FRAGRANCE OF OUR FLOWERY MEADS
translated_text: Other sweet herbs are cultivated for purposes of medicine and perfumery. They are most grateful both to the organs of taste and smelling, and to the aroma derived from them is due in a great measure the sweet and exhilarating fragrance of our flowery needs.

text: FRENCH FORCEMEAT
translated_text: French Force Meat

text: IT WILL BE WELL TO STATE IN THE BEGINNING OF THIS RECIPE THAT FRENCH FORCEMEAT OR QUENELLES CONSIST OF THE BLENDING OF THREE SEPARATE PROCESSES NAMELY PANADA UDDER AND WHATEVER MEAT YOU INTEND USING PANADA
translated_text: It will be well to state in the beginning of this recipe that French Forced Meat or Cornels consists of the blending of three separate processes, namely Panada, Udder, and whatever meat you intend using. Panada

text: PLACE IT OVER THE FIRE KEEP CONSTANTLY STIRRING TO PREVENT ITS BURNING AND WHEN QUITE DRY PUT IN A SMALL PIECE OF BUTTER
translated_text: Place it over the fire, keep constantly stirring to prevent its burning, and when quite dry, put in a small piece of butter.

text: PUT THE UDDER INTO A STEWPAN WITH SUFFICIENT WATER TO COVER IT LET IT STEW GENTLY TILL QUITE DONE WHEN TAKE IT OUT TO COOL
translated_text: Put the edger into a stew pan with sufficient water to cover it. Let it stew gently till quite done, when take it out to cool.

text: ILLUSTRATION PESTLE AND MORTAR
translated_text: Illustration, Pestil and Mortar.

text: WHEN THE THREE INGREDIENTS ARE PROPERLY PREPARED POUND THEM ALTOGETHER IN A MORTAR FOR SOME TIME FOR THE MORE QUENELLES ARE POUNDED THE MORE DELICATE THEY ARE
translated_text: When the three ingredients are properly prepared, pound them all together in a mortar for some time. For the more canals are pounded, the more delicate they are.

text: IF THE QUENELLES ARE NOT FIRM ENOUGH ADD THE YOLK OF ANOTHER EGG BUT OMIT THE WHITE WHICH ONLY MAKES THEM HOLLOW AND PUFFY INSIDE
translated_text: If the quenelles are not firm enough, add the yolk of another egg, but omit the white, which only makes them hollow and puffy inside.

text: ANY ONE WITH THE SLIGHTEST PRETENSIONS TO REFINED COOKERY MUST IN THIS PARTICULAR IMPLICITLY FOLLOW THE EXAMPLE OF OUR FRIENDS ACROSS THE CHANNEL
translated_text: Anyone with the slightest pretentions to refine cooked green must, in this particular, implicitly follow the example of our friends across the channel.

text: FRIED BREAD CRUMBS
translated_text: Fried breadcrumbs.

text: THE FAT THEY ARE FRIED IN SHOULD BE CLEAR AND THE CRUMBS SHOULD NOT HAVE THE SLIGHTEST APPEARANCE OR TASTE OF HAVING BEEN IN THE LEAST DEGREE BURNT
translated_text: The fat there fried and should be clear, and the crumbs should not have the slightest appearance or taste of having been in the least degree burnt.

text: FRIED BREAD FOR BORDERS
translated_text: Fried bread for borders.

text: WHEN QUITE CRISP DIP ONE SIDE OF THE SIPPET INTO THE BEATEN WHITE OF AN EGG MIXED WITH A LITTLE FLOUR AND PLACE IT ON THE EDGE OF THE DISH
translated_text: When quite crisp, dip one side of the sippet into the beaten white of an egg mixed with a little flour and place it on the edge of the dish.

text: CONTINUE IN THIS MANNER TILL THE BORDER IS COMPLETED ARRANGING THE SIPPETS A PALE AND A DARK ONE ALTERNATELY
translated_text: Continue in this manner till the border is completed, arranging the cipits of pale and a dark one alternately.

text: MODE CUT UP THE ONION AND CARROT INTO SMALL RINGS AND PUT THEM INTO A STEWPAN WITH THE HERBS MUSHROOMS BAY LEAF CLOVES AND MACE ADD THE BUTTER AND SIMMER THE WHOLE VERY GENTLY OVER A SLOW FIRE UNTIL THE ONION IS QUITE TENDER
translated_text: Mode. Cut up the onion and carrot into small rings and put them into a stew pan with herbs, mushrooms, bay leaf, cloves and mace. Add the butter and simmer the whole very gently over a slow fire until the onion is quite tender.

text: SUFFICIENT HALF THIS QUANTITY FOR TWO SLICES OF SALMON
translated_text: sufficient half this quantity for two slices of salmon.

text: ILLUSTRATION SAGE
translated_text: Illustration, Sage.

text: FUCHS BROUGHT UP A SACK OF POTATOES AND A PIECE OF CURED PORK FROM THE CELLAR AND GRANDMOTHER PACKED SOME LOAVES OF SATURDAY'S BREAD A JAR OF BUTTER AND SEVERAL PUMPKIN PIES IN THE STRAW OF THE WAGON BOX
translated_text: Fooks brought up a sack of potatoes, and a piece of cured pork from the cellar. And grandmother packed some loaves of Saturday's bread, a jar of butter, and several pumpkin pies in the straw of the wagon box.

text: OCCASIONALLY ONE OF THE HORSES WOULD TEAR OFF WITH HIS TEETH A PLANT FULL OF BLOSSOMS AND WALK ALONG MUNCHING IT THE FLOWERS NODDING IN TIME TO HIS BITES AS HE ATE DOWN TOWARD THEM
translated_text: Occasionally, one of the horses would tear off with his teeth, a plant full of blossoms, and walk along munching it, the flowers nodding in time to his bites as he ate down toward them.

text: IT'S NO BETTER THAN A BADGER HOLE NO PROPER DUGOUT AT ALL
translated_text: It's no better than a badger hole. No proper dugout at all.

text: NOW WHY IS THAT OTTO
translated_text: Now, why is that auto?

text: PRESENTLY AGAINST ONE OF THOSE BANKS I SAW A SORT OF SHED THATCHED WITH THE SAME WINE COLORED GRASS THAT GREW EVERYWHERE
translated_text: Presently, against one of those banks, I saw a sort of shed, thatched with the same wine-colored grass that grew everywhere.

text: VERY GLAD VERY GLAD SHE EJACULATED
translated_text: Very glad, very glad she ejaculated.

text: YOU'LL GET FIXED UP COMFORTABLE AFTER WHILE MISSUS SHIMERDA MAKE GOOD HOUSE
translated_text: You'll get fixed up comfortable after a while Mrs. Schumerida. Make good house.

text: MY GRANDMOTHER ALWAYS SPOKE IN A VERY LOUD TONE TO FOREIGNERS AS IF THEY WERE DEAF
translated_text: My grandmother always spoke in a very loud tone to foreigners, as if they were deaf.

text: SHE MADE MISSUS SHIMERDA UNDERSTAND THE FRIENDLY INTENTION OF OUR VISIT AND THE BOHEMIAN WOMAN HANDLED THE LOAVES OF BREAD AND EVEN SMELLED THEM AND EXAMINED THE PIES WITH LIVELY CURIOSITY EXCLAIMING MUCH GOOD MUCH THANK
translated_text: She made Mrs. Shamir to understand the friendly intention of our visit, and the Bohemian woman handled the loaves of bread, and even smelled them, and examined the pies with lively curiosity, exclaiming, much good, much think!

text: THE FAMILY HAD BEEN LIVING ON CORNCAKES AND SORGHUM MOLASSES FOR THREE DAYS
translated_text: The family had been living on corn cakes and sorghum molasses for three days.

text: I REMEMBERED WHAT THE CONDUCTOR HAD SAID ABOUT HER EYES
translated_text: I remembered what the conductor had said about her eyes.

text: HER SKIN WAS BROWN TOO AND IN HER CHEEKS SHE HAD A GLOW OF RICH DARK COLOR
translated_text: Her skin was brown too, and in her cheeks she had a glow of rich dark color.

text: EVEN FROM A DISTANCE ONE COULD SEE THAT THERE WAS SOMETHING STRANGE ABOUT THIS BOY
translated_text: Even from a distance, one could see that there was something strange about this boy.

text: HE WAS BORN LIKE THAT THE OTHERS ARE SMART
translated_text: He was born like that. The others are smart.

text: AMBROSCH HE MAKE GOOD FARMER
translated_text: Ambrose, you make good farmer.

text: HE STRUCK AMBROSCH ON THE BACK AND THE BOY SMILED KNOWINGLY
translated_text: He struck Ambrose on the back, and the boy smiled knowingly.

text: AT THAT MOMENT THE FATHER CAME OUT OF THE HOLE IN THE BANK
translated_text: At that moment the father came out of the hole in the bank.

text: IT WAS SO LONG THAT IT BUSHED OUT BEHIND HIS EARS AND MADE HIM LOOK LIKE THE OLD PORTRAITS I REMEMBERED IN VIRGINIA
translated_text: It was so long that it busched out behind his ears and made him look like the old portraits I remember in Virginia.

text: I NOTICED HOW WHITE AND WELL SHAPED HIS OWN HANDS WERE
translated_text: I noticed how white and well shaped his own hands were.

text: WE STOOD PANTING ON THE EDGE OF THE RAVINE LOOKING DOWN AT THE TREES AND BUSHES THAT GREW BELOW US
translated_text: We stood panting on the edge of the ravine, looking down at the trees and bushes that grew below us.

text: THE WIND WAS SO STRONG THAT I HAD TO HOLD MY HAT ON AND THE GIRLS SKIRTS WERE BLOWN OUT BEFORE THEM
translated_text: The wind was so strong that I had to hold my hat on and the girl's skirts were blown out before them.

text: SHE LOOKED AT ME HER EYES FAIRLY BLAZING WITH THINGS SHE COULD NOT SAY
translated_text: She looked at me, her eyes fairly blazing with things she could not say.

text: SHE POINTED INTO THE GOLD COTTONWOOD TREE BEHIND WHOSE TOP WE STOOD AND SAID AGAIN WHAT NAME
translated_text: She pointed into the gold cottonwood tree behind his top we stood and said again, What name?

text: ANTONIA POINTED UP TO THE SKY AND QUESTIONED ME WITH HER GLANCE
translated_text: Antonia pointed up to the sky and questioned me with her glance.

text: SHE GOT UP ON HER KNEES AND WRUNG HER HANDS
translated_text: She got up on her knees and wrong her hands.

text: SHE WAS QUICK AND VERY EAGER
translated_text: She was quick and very eager.

text: WE WERE SO DEEP IN THE GRASS THAT WE COULD SEE NOTHING BUT THE BLUE SKY OVER US AND THE GOLD TREE IN FRONT OF US
translated_text: We were so deep in the grass that we could see nothing but the blue sky over us, and the gold tree in front of us.

text: AFTER ANTONIA HAD SAID THE NEW WORDS OVER AND OVER SHE WANTED TO GIVE ME A LITTLE CHASED SILVER RING SHE WORE ON HER MIDDLE FINGER
translated_text: After Antonya had said the new words over and over, she wanted to give me a little chased silver ring she wore on her middle finger.

text: WHEN I CAME UP HE TOUCHED MY SHOULDER AND LOOKED SEARCHINGLY DOWN INTO MY FACE FOR SEVERAL SECONDS
translated_text: When I came up, he touched my shoulder and looked searchingly down into my face for several seconds.

text: I BECAME SOMEWHAT EMBARRASSED FOR I WAS USED TO BEING TAKEN FOR GRANTED BY MY ELDERS
translated_text: I became somewhat embarrassed for I was used to being taken for granted by my elders.

text: IN ARISTOCRATIC COMMUNITIES THE PEOPLE READILY GIVE THEMSELVES UP TO BURSTS OF TUMULTUOUS AND BOISTEROUS GAYETY WHICH SHAKE OFF AT ONCE THE RECOLLECTION OF THEIR PRIVATIONS THE NATIVES OF DEMOCRACIES ARE NOT FOND OF BEING THUS VIOLENTLY BROKEN IN UPON AND THEY NEVER LOSE SIGHT OF THEIR OWN SELVES WITHOUT REGRET
translated_text: In aristocratic communities, the people readily give themselves up to bursts of tumultuous and boisterous guillity, which shake off at once the recollection of their privations. The natives of democracies are not fond of being thus violently broken in upon, and they never lose sight of their own selves without regret.

text: AN AMERICAN INSTEAD OF GOING IN A LEISURE HOUR TO DANCE MERRILY AT SOME PLACE OF PUBLIC RESORT AS THE FELLOWS OF HIS CALLING CONTINUE TO DO THROUGHOUT THE GREATER PART OF EUROPE SHUTS HIMSELF UP AT HOME TO DRINK
translated_text: An American, instead of going in a leisure hour to dance merrily at some place of public resort, as the fellows of his co-ling continue to do throughout the greater part of Europe, shut himself up at home to drink.

text: I BELIEVE THE SERIOUSNESS OF THE AMERICANS ARISES PARTLY FROM THEIR PRIDE
translated_text: I believe the seriousness of the Americans arises partly from their pride.

text: THIS IS MORE ESPECIALLY THE CASE AMONGST THOSE FREE NATIONS WHICH FORM DEMOCRATIC COMMUNITIES
translated_text: This is more especially the case amongst those free nations which form democratic communities.

text: THEN THERE ARE IN ALL CLASSES A VERY LARGE NUMBER OF MEN CONSTANTLY OCCUPIED WITH THE SERIOUS AFFAIRS OF THE GOVERNMENT AND THOSE WHOSE THOUGHTS ARE NOT ENGAGED IN THE DIRECTION OF THE COMMONWEALTH ARE WHOLLY ENGROSSED BY THE ACQUISITION OF A PRIVATE FORTUNE
translated_text: Then there are, in all classes, a very large number of men constantly occupied with the series affairs of the government, and those whose thoughts are not engaged in the direction of the Commonwealth are wholly engrossed by the acquisition of a private fortune.

text: I DO NOT BELIEVE IN SUCH REPUBLICS ANY MORE THAN IN THAT OF PLATO OR IF THE THINGS WE READ OF REALLY HAPPENED I DO NOT HESITATE TO AFFIRM THAT THESE SUPPOSED DEMOCRACIES WERE COMPOSED OF VERY DIFFERENT ELEMENTS FROM OURS AND THAT THEY HAD NOTHING IN COMMON WITH THE LATTER EXCEPT THEIR NAME
translated_text: I do not believe in such republics anymore than in that of Plato. Or if the things we read off really happened, I do not hesitate to affirm that these supposed democracies were composed of very different elements from ours, and that they had nothing in common with the letter except their name.

text: IN ARISTOCRACIES EVERY MAN HAS ONE SOLE OBJECT WHICH HE UNCEASINGLY PURSUES BUT AMONGST DEMOCRATIC NATIONS THE EXISTENCE OF MAN IS MORE COMPLEX THE SAME MIND WILL ALMOST ALWAYS EMBRACE SEVERAL OBJECTS AT THE SAME TIME AND THESE OBJECTS ARE FREQUENTLY WHOLLY FOREIGN TO EACH OTHER AS IT CANNOT KNOW THEM ALL WELL THE MIND IS READILY SATISFIED WITH IMPERFECT NOTIONS OF EACH
translated_text: In aristocracies, every man has one soul object which he unceasingly pursues. But amongst democratic nations, the existence of man is more complex. The same mind will almost always embrace several objects at the same time, and these objects are frequently wholly foreign to each other. As it cannot know them all well, the mind is readily satisfied with imperfect notions of each.

text: CHAPTER SIXTEEN WHY THE NATIONAL VANITY OF THE AMERICANS IS MORE RESTLESS AND CAPTIOUS THAN THAT OF THE ENGLISH
translated_text: Chapter 16. Why the national vanity of the Americans is more restless and captures than that of the English?

text: THE AMERICANS IN THEIR INTERCOURSE WITH STRANGERS APPEAR IMPATIENT OF THE SMALLEST CENSURE AND INSATIABLE OF PRAISE
translated_text: The Americans in their intercourse with strangers appear impatient with the smallest center, an insatiable of praise.

text: IF I SAY TO AN AMERICAN THAT THE COUNTRY HE LIVES IN IS A FINE ONE AY HE REPLIES THERE IS NOT ITS FELLOW IN THE WORLD
translated_text: If I say to an American that the country he lives in is a fine one. I, he replies, there is not its fellow in the world.

text: IF I APPLAUD THE FREEDOM WHICH ITS INHABITANTS ENJOY HE ANSWERS FREEDOM IS A FINE THING BUT FEW NATIONS ARE WORTHY TO ENJOY IT
translated_text: If I applaud the freedom which its inhabitants enjoy, he answers, Freedom is a fine thing, but few nations are worthy to enjoy it.

text: IN ARISTOCRATIC COUNTRIES THE GREAT POSSESS IMMENSE PRIVILEGES UPON WHICH THEIR PRIDE RESTS WITHOUT SEEKING TO RELY UPON THE LESSER ADVANTAGES WHICH ACCRUE TO THEM
translated_text: In aristocratic countries, the great possess immense privileges upon which their pride rests without seeking to rely upon the lesser advantages which accruise at them.

text: THEY THEREFORE ENTERTAIN A CALM SENSE OF THEIR SUPERIORITY THEY DO NOT DREAM OF VAUNTING PRIVILEGES WHICH EVERYONE PERCEIVES AND NO ONE CONTESTS AND THESE THINGS ARE NOT SUFFICIENTLY NEW TO THEM TO BE MADE TOPICS OF CONVERSATION
translated_text: They therefore entertain a calm sense of their superiority. They do not dream of vanting privileges, which everyone perceives, at no one contests. And these things are not sufficiently new to them to be made topics of conversation.

text: THEY STAND UNMOVED IN THEIR SOLITARY GREATNESS WELL ASSURED THAT THEY ARE SEEN OF ALL THE WORLD WITHOUT ANY EFFORT TO SHOW THEMSELVES OFF AND THAT NO ONE WILL ATTEMPT TO DRIVE THEM FROM THAT POSITION
translated_text: They stand unmoved in their solitary greatness, well as sure that they are seen of all the world without any effort to show themselves off, and that no one will attempt to drive them from that position.

text: WHEN AN ARISTOCRACY CARRIES ON THE PUBLIC AFFAIRS ITS NATIONAL PRIDE NATURALLY ASSUMES THIS RESERVED INDIFFERENT AND HAUGHTY FORM WHICH IS IMITATED BY ALL THE OTHER CLASSES OF THE NATION
translated_text: When an aristocracy carries on the public affairs, its national pride naturally assumes this reserved, indifferent, and haughty form, which is imitated by all the other classes of the nation.

text: THESE PERSONS THEN DISPLAYED TOWARDS EACH OTHER PRECISELY THE SAME PUERILE JEALOUSIES WHICH ANIMATE THE MEN OF DEMOCRACIES THE SAME EAGERNESS TO SNATCH THE SMALLEST ADVANTAGES WHICH THEIR EQUALS CONTESTED AND THE SAME DESIRE TO PARADE OSTENTATIOUSLY THOSE OF WHICH THEY WERE IN POSSESSION
translated_text: These persons then, displayed towards each other, precisely the same pure-all jealousies which animate the men of democracies, the same eagerness to snatch the small advantages which are equals contested, and the same desire to parade ostentatiously those of which they were in possession.

text: THE TWO STRAY KITTENS GRADUALLY MAKE THEMSELVES AT HOME
translated_text: The two stray kittens gradually make themselves at home.

text: SOMEHOW OR OTHER CAT HAS TAUGHT THEM THAT HE'S IN CHARGE HERE AND HE JUST CHASES THEM FOR FUN NOW AND AGAIN WHEN HE'S NOT BUSY SLEEPING
translated_text: Somehow or other, Cat has taught them that he's in charge here, and he just chases them for fun now and again when he's not busy sleeping.

text: SHE DOESN'T PICK THEM UP BUT JUST HAVING THEM IN THE ROOM SURE DOESN'T GIVE HER ASTHMA
translated_text: She doesn't pick them up, but just having them in the room sure doesn't give her asthma.

text: WHEN ARE YOU GETTING RID OF THESE CATS I'M NOT FIXING TO START AN ANNEX TO KATE'S CAT HOME
translated_text: When are you getting rid of these cats? I'm not fixing to start an annex to Kate's cat home.

text: RIGHT AWAY WHEN I BRING HOME MY NEW PROGRAM HE SAYS HOW COME YOU'RE TAKING ONE LESS COURSE THIS HALF
translated_text: Right away, when I bring home my new program, he says, how come you're taking one less course this half?

text: I EXPLAIN THAT I'M TAKING MUSIC AND ALSO BIOLOGY ALGEBRA ENGLISH AND FRENCH MUSIC HE SNORTS
